statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Mississippi 91, Alabama 88
article.story: OXFORD, Miss. (AP) -- Chris Warren scored 25 points and Dwayne Curtis chipped in 24, including a pair of decisive free throws with 16 seconds left, as Mississippi beat Alabama 91-88 on Saturday. Curtis' free throws gave the Rebels (19-9, 5-9 Southeastern Conference) a 91-86 lead. But Alabama's Demetrius Jamison hit a jumper to cut the margin to 91-88 with 7.9 seconds left. That's when things got strange. Senario Hillman came up with a steal for Alabama and missed a 3-pointer. Curtis grabbed a rebound for Ole Miss with 2.5 seconds left, but the game clock suddenly froze. Players stood around wondering what was going on. Game officials conferred, and after using a stop watch, determined the game ended with Curtis in possession of the defensive rebound. The bizarre finish overshadowed an Alabama rally that nearly erased a 15-point deficit in the final 2:03. The Crimson Tide (15-14, 4-10) hit seven consecutive field goals and three free throws before Hillman's final game-tying attempt with six seconds left. David Huertas 18 points and nine rebounds for the Rebels, who kept their slim NCAA Tournament hopes alive by winning for the second time in the past three starts. The game was tied 38-38 at halftime. Mykal Riley led Alabama with 20 points, Jamison had 17, Rico Pickett and Hillman had 13 each and Richard Hendrix scored 10 points. The Rebels shot 75 percent from the field in the second half, but needed six consecutive free throws by Curtis and Warren in the final minutes to preserve the win.
